Award.AwardTitle: Finite Time Lyapunov Analysis in Optimal Control

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research aims to develop methodology for optimally controlled systems that evolve on two or more disparate timescales. At the heart of the approach is the use of finite-time Lyapunov exponents and vectors associated with the linearized dynamics along trajectories of the Hamiltonian system that, with the appropriate boundary conditions, augments the original dynamics with the first-order necessary conditions for optimality and governs the evolution of the optimally controlled system. The timescales are diagnosed from the spectrum of exponents. Geometric structure is identified by using Lyapunov vectors to construct the appropriate partially hyperbolic splitting of the tangent bundle to the phase space for the Hamiltonian system and to formulate conditions satisfied by phase points on key manifolds. The capability of calculating points on key manifolds enables a solution approximation method in which the hyper-sensitivity due to the disparate timescales is suppressed. The finite-time Lyapunov exponents and vectors also provide information that aids the development of implementable near-optimal control laws. Deliverables include analysis methods and tools, application to and validation of the methodology to problems in flight mechanics and robotics, documentation of research results, and engineering student education.

Optimal control of machines, structures, and vehicles is of increasing importance in this era of demands for both high performance and efficient operation. Yet obtaining solutions to optimal control problems and especially developing near-optimal implementable control laws is often difficult. A common source of this difficulty is hyper-sensitivity which is problematic for many numerical solution approaches, yet it implies a geometric structure in the solution space, knowledge of which can lead to simplified solution approaches, greater understanding, and implementable near-optimal control laws. If successful, the project results will facilitate the implementation of high performance, efficient controllers for engineered systems. The methodology is expected to benefit other application areas, such as weather prediction and chemical kinetics, where understanding timescales and manifold structure has value.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Optimal control of machines, structures, vehicles, and other civil and mechanical systems is of increasing importance in this era of demands for both high performance and efficient operation. Yet obtaining solutions to optimal control problems is often difficult. A common source of this difficulty is hyper-sensitivity due to multiple timescales. However, while hyper-sensitivity is problematic for many numerical solution approaches, it implies a geometric structure in the solution space, knowledge of which can lead to simplified solution approaches, greater understanding of the optimal dynamics, and implementable near-optimal control laws.

Methodology has been developed for diagnosing hyper-sensitivity, identifying the geometric structure of the phase space, and approximating solutions, based on the geometric information, for optimally-controlled dynamical systems that are nonlinear, autonomous, and finite-dimensional. We analyze the Hamiltonian system of twice the dimension that, with the appropriate boundary conditions, augments the original dynamics with the first-order necessary conditions for optimality. At the heart of the approach is the use of finite-time Lyapunov exponents and vectors associated with the linearized dynamics along trajectories of the Hamiltonian system. Hyper-sensitivity is diagnosed from the spectrum of exponents. Geometric structure is identified by using Lyapunov vectors to construct the appropriate partially hyperbolic splitting of the tangent bundle to the phase space for the Hamiltonian system and to formulate conditions satisfied by phase points on key manifolds, e.g., center, fast-stable, and fast-unstable. The capability of calculating points on key manifolds enables a solution approximation method in which the hyper-sensitivity is suppressed. The finite-time Lyapunov exponents and vectors also provide information that aids the development of implementable near-optimal control laws.

To further develop the methodology and transition it to practice, we applied our Finite-time Lyapunov Analysis (FTLA) to problems in spacecraft dynamics and robotics. In particular, the methodology was applied to maneuvers of spacecraft orbiting Lagrangian points in the Circular Restricted Three-Body Problem. We used FTLA-based methods to improve existing station-keeping strategies. Ph.D. student Marco Maggia was deeply involved in the project and some of our results have been summarized in a journal paper. FTLA was also applied to the optimal control of robots. For the problem of minimizing the control effort required to extend a multi-link robotic arm, FTLA was used to approximate the optimal solution. The project involved Ph.D. students Joan Aguilar and Marco Maggia.
